Package javelin.model.world.location.dungeon

Class Dungeon

  • java.lang.Object
    • javelin.model.world.Actor
      • javelin.model.world.location.Location
        • javelin.model.world.location.dungeon.Dungeon
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Megadungeon, TempleDungeon, Wilderness
    public class Dungeon
extends Location
    A dungeon is an underground area of the world where the combats are harder but have extra treasure laying around. The in-game logic for dungeons is that they are a hideout of bandits or similar, which is why they are sacrificeable by Incursions and are removed from the game after a Squad leaves one (in this case it's assumed the bandits packed their stuff and left).
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • encounters

        public java.util.List<Combatants> encounters
        Table of encounters to roll from when generating RandomDungeonEncounters. Entries can be set to null when certain encounters are pacified. If rolled, these will result in skipped encounters (ie: the Squad met them but they weren't hostile). Pacified encounters do not carry over to the next level.
        See Also:
        Leader

      • floors

        protected java.util.List<? extends Dungeon> floors
        All floors that make part of this dungeon.

      • activate

        public void activate​(boolean loading)
        Create or recreate dungeon.

      • define

        public void define()
        This function generates the dungeon map using DungeonGenerator and then #createfeatures(int). One notable thing that happens here is the determination of how many RandomDungeonEncounters should take for the player to explore the whole level. Currently, the calculation is done by setting a goal of one fight per room on average (so naturally, larger DungeonTiers will have more fights than smaller ones). The formula takes into account DungeonScreen#VIEWRADIUS instead of counting each step as a single tile. Since a Squad of the dungeon's intended level cannot hope to clear a dungeon if it's large (in average they can only take 4-5 encounters of the same EL), this is then offset by placing enough fountains that would theoretically allow them to do the one dungeon in one go. This is currently not counting backtracking out of the dungeon or finding your way back to town safely, so this naturally makes the dungeon more challenging (hopefully being offset by the rewards inside).
